facts.text: Original Jurisdiction Petition No. 328 of 1951

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 328 of 1951.Petition under article 32 of the Constitution for issue of writs in the nature of certiorari, prohibition and mandamus. The facts appear in the judgment.

facts.text: Petition under article 32 of the Constitution for writs of certiorari, prohibition and mandamus

anchor.surface_text: Petition under article 32 of the Constitution for issue of writs in the nature of certiorari, prohibition and mandamus. The facts appear in the judgment. The petitioner in person. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India,  J. B. Dadachanji, with him  for the respondent.

facts.text: Petitioner appeared in person

anchor.surface_text: The facts appear in the judgment. The petitioner in person. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India,  J. B. Dadachanji, with him  for the respondent. 1951. December 21.

facts.text: K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, and J. B. Dadachanji appeared for the respondent

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner in person. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India,  J. B. Dadachanji, with him  for the respondent. 1951. December 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by PATANJALI SASTRI.C.J.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on 1951 December 21 by PATANJALI SASTRI C.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1951. December 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by PATANJALI SASTRI.C.J.--This is a petition under article 32 of the Constitution for the enforcement of the petition- ers fundamental rights under article 19  1   f  and article 31  1  alleged to have been violated by the Central Bank of India Ltd.,

facts.text: Petition under article 32 for enforcement of petitioner's fundamental rights under article 19(1)(f) and article 31(1)

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by PATANJALI SASTRI.C.J.--This is a petition under article 32 of the Constitution for the enforcement of the petition- ers fundamental rights under article 19  1   f  and article 31  1  alleged to have been violated by the Central Bank of India Ltd., a companypany incorporated under the Indian Compa-

facts.text: Rights alleged violated by Central Bank of India Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: alleged to have been violated by the Central Bank of India Ltd., a companypany incorporated under the Indian Compa- nies Act, 1882, and having its registered office at Bombay,  hereinafter referred to as the Bank . It appears that the petitioner held five shares in the Share capital of the Bank which sold those shales to a third party

facts.text: Central Bank of India Ltd. incorporated under Indian Companies Act, 1882, registered office at Bombay

anchor.surface_text: Central Bank of India Ltd., a companypany incorporated under the Indian Compa- nies Act, 1882, and having its registered office at Bombay,  hereinafter referred to as the Bank . It appears that the petitioner held five shares in the Share capital of the Bank which sold those shales to a third party in purported exercise of its right of lien

facts.text: Petitioner held five shares in the share capital of the Bank

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the petitioner held five shares in the Share capital of the Bank which sold those shales to a third party in purported exercise of its right of lien for recovery of a debt due to it from the petitioner, and the transfer was registered in the books of the Bank in the year 1937.

facts.text: Bank sold the five shares to a third party in purported exercise of its right of lien for recovery of a debt due from the petitioner

anchor.surface_text: the petitioner held five shares in the Share capital of the Bank which sold those shales to a third party in purported exercise of its right of lien for recovery of a debt due to it from the petitioner, and the transfer was registered in the books of the Bank in the year 1937. The petitioner thereupon instituted a series of pro-

facts.text: Transfer of shares registered in the books of the Bank in the year 1937

anchor.surface_text: and the transfer was registered in the books of the Bank in the year 1937. The petitioner thereupon instituted a series of pro- ceedings in the High Court at Bombay on its original and appellate jurisdiction challenging the validity of the said sale and transfer.

facts.text: Petitioner instituted a series of proceedings in the High Court at Bombay on its original and appellate jurisdiction challenging the validity of the sale and transfer

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner thereupon instituted a series of pro- ceedings in the High Court at Bombay on its original and appellate jurisdiction challenging the validity of the said sale and transfer. The latest of these proceedings was a suit filed against the Bank in 1951 wherein the plaint was rejected on 2nd March, 1951,

facts.text: Latest proceeding: suit filed against the Bank in 1951

anchor.surface_text: The latest of these proceedings was a suit filed against the Bank in 1951 wherein the plaint was rejected on 2nd March, 1951, under Order 7, Rule 11  d , of the Code of Civil Procedure as barred by limitation.

facts.text: Plaint in the 1951 suit rejected on 2nd March 1951 under Order 7 Rule 11(d) CPC as barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: wherein the plaint was rejected on 2nd March, 1951, under Order 7, Rule 11  d , of the Code of Civil Procedure as barred by limitation. The petitioner number prays that all the adverse orders made in the previous proceedings be quashed and the said High Court be directed to have the above suit set down to be heard as undefended

facts.text: Petitioner prays that all adverse orders in previous proceedings be quashed

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner number prays that all the adverse orders made in the previous proceedings be quashed and the said High Court be directed to have the above suit set down to be heard as undefended and pronounce judgment against the respondent or to make such orders as it thinks fit in relation to the said suit.

facts.text: Petitioner prays that High Court be directed to set down the suit to be heard as undefended and pronounce judgment against the respondent

anchor.surface_text: and the said High Court be directed to have the above suit set down to be heard as undefended and pronounce judgment against the respondent or to make such orders as it thinks fit in relation to the said suit. It may be mentioned here that though the aforesaid order rejecting the petitioners plaint was appealable,

facts.text: Order rejecting petitioner's plaint was appealable

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned here that though the aforesaid order rejecting the petitioners plaint was appealable, the petitioner did number prefer an appeal on the somewhat extraor- dinary ground that the appeal if filed companyld number be heard by the Judges of the said Court as all of them were disqual- ified from hearing such appeal either because of their interest in the Bank or because of their prejudice against him.

facts.text: Petitioner did not prefer an appeal against the order rejecting the plaint

anchor.surface_text: the petitioner did number prefer an appeal on the somewhat extraor- dinary ground that the appeal if filed companyld number be heard by the Judges of the said Court as all of them were disqual- ified from hearing such appeal either because of their interest

facts.text: Petitioner claimed judges of High Court disqualified from hearing appeal due to interest in Bank or prejudice against him

anchor.surface_text: dinary ground that the appeal if filed companyld number be heard by the Judges of the said Court as all of them were disqual- ified from hearing such appeal either because of their interest in the Bank or because of their prejudice against him. We are of opinion that the petitioner has misconceived his remedy and the petition must fail on a preliminary ground.

facts.text: Court held that petitioner misconceived his remedy and petition must fail on preliminary ground

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the petitioner has misconceived his remedy and the petition must fail on a preliminary ground. Neither article 19  1   f  number article 31  1  on its true companystruction was intended to prevent wrongful individual acts or to provide protection against merely private companyduct.

holdings.text: The petitioner has misconceived his remedy and the petition must fail on a preliminary ground because neither Article 19(1)(f) nor Article 31(1) on its true construction was intended to prevent wrongful individual acts or to provide protection against merely private conduct.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the petitioner has misconceived his remedy and the petition must fail on a preliminary ground. Neither article 19  1   f  number article 31  1  on its true companystruction was intended to prevent wrongful individual acts or to provide protection against merely private companyduct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Language, structure, and placement in Part III indicate protection only against State action, not private conduct.

holdings.text: Article 19 was intended to protect freedoms including the freedom to acquire, hold and dispose of property against State action other than in the legitimate exercise of its power to regulate private rights in the public interest; violation of property rights by individuals is not within the purview of the article.

anchor.surface_text: Article 19 deals with the right to free- dom and by clause  1  assures to the citizen certain funda- mental freedoms including the freedom to acquire, hold and dispose of property subject to the power of the State

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article deals with freedoms subject to State restrictions; setting in Part III shows protection against State, not individuals.

holdings.text: The position is no better under Article 31(1); it prohibits unauthorised governmental action against private property.

anchor.surface_text: The position is numberbetter under article 31  1 . The petitioner has urged that clause  1  should be companystrued apart from and independently of the rest of the article and, if so companystrued, its language is wide enough to companyer in-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same rationale as Article 19(1)(f); words 'save by authority of law' exclude private deprivation.

holdings.text: Even assuming Article 31(1) is to be construed apart from the rest of the article, it protects against governmental action only, like Article 21, as 'save by authority of law' excludes private individuals who cannot be authorised by law to deprive others of property.

anchor.surface_text: where the view was expressed that clause  1 enunciated the general principle that numberperson should be deprived  1  1950 S.C,R,. 860. of his property except by authority of law and laid down numbercondition for payment of companypensation, while clause  2  dealt with deprivation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to Article 21 which lacks 'State' but protects only against State via 'procedure established by law'; no private authorisation possible.

holdings.text: There is no force in the argument that Article 31(1) should be construed apart from the rest of the article to cover private infringements.

anchor.surface_text: We see numberforce in any of these arguments. In support of the argument that clause  1   should be companystrued in isolation from the rest of the article, the petitioner relied on certain observations of our learned brother Das in Chiranjit Lal v. The Union of India  1 ,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to decide isolation but even if so, does not extend to private acts; rejects reliance on Chiranjit Lal.

holdings.text: Omission of the word 'State' in Article 31(1) does not indicate protection against private individuals.

anchor.surface_text: Its restoration, therefore, in the same form in article 31, after omission in the original draft article 19, companyld lead to numberinference in support c. of the peti- tioners companytention, which indeed proceeds on the fundamen-

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Save by authority of law' excludes private acts regardless of 'State' omission.

holdings.text: The argument based on absence of specific entries in the Seventh Schedule for deprivation of property is fallacious; legislatures have competence under other entries like Entry 1 of Lists II and III.

anchor.surface_text: The argument based on the entries in the Lists is fallacious. It is number companyrect to suggest that, merely be- cause there is numberentry in the Lists of the Seventh Schedule relating to deprivation of property as such, it is number within the companypetence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deprivation laws possible under general entries; Article 31(1) contemplates authorising laws.

holdings.text: The legislative history of Article 31(1), including its restoration after omission in draft Article 19, lends no support to protection against private deprivation.

anchor.surface_text: Nor does the legislative history of the article lend any support to the petitioners companytention. Section 299  1  of the Government of India Act, 1935, was never inter- preted as prohibiting deprivation of property by private individuals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 299(1) of 1935 Act never interpreted against private acts; restoration implies no change.

holdings.text: Articles 19(1)(f) and 31(1) are constitutional safeguards against State aggression on private property; infringements by private individuals are remedied by ordinary law.

anchor.surface_text: tioners companytention, which indeed proceeds on the fundamen- tal misconception that article 19 1  f  and article 31  1 , which are great companystitutional safeguards against State aggression on private property, are directed against in- fringements by private individuals for which remedies should be sought in the ordinary law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fundamental rights directed vertically against State, not horizontally; ordinary law for private wrongs.
